segments.text: Back around 1840 or so, it was common knowledge that all stars had planets around them.
And then the Chamberlain-Morton Theories came along, and then we were a cosmic freak.
The solar system was the only solar system in the observable universe.
came along and rehabilitated the nebular hypothesis.
got to be in the space age, you know, the idea that solar systems are common.
And, of course, the literature is littered with claims of detecting planets around other stars that don't hang up.
What's your opinion?
Are solar systems, in the sense of ours, not just as they're a rock floating around some of the stars, common or uncommon?
Yeah, you're right.
Every time somebody discovers a planet around a neighboring star, they don't usually pan out.
Well, in the sense that there are almost certainly other planets around other stars, I don't think there's a question to that.
Life is more than any other planet.
This is another question.
Is that the question you're asking?
Here's going to be the next one.
Again, if you go back to 1840 or 1870, every planet's inhabited.
Then you get to the early part of this century with H.G.
Wells, who was very negative about it.
We were a cosmic freak.
Well, now lately people have been searching for extraterrestrial intelligence by radio means and so forth.
But lately it seems to me that it's getting back to the cosmic freak again.
What's your opinion?
No, I quite agree.
I think that's the trend that we're moving toward.
You're right, about 10 years ago,
planets were ubiquitous around most stars, and a certain percentage of those, well, you could work it out with Drake's equation there.
It made all kinds of sense.
If you put in the numbers, there was a certain percentage of those planets that were inhabited.
Well, where are they?
They're not making a concerted effort to get in touch with us, so now you have to start asking yourself, well, maybe they're not there.
Yeah, I think that's right.
I think there is a realization that if we're not alone, we don't have too many neighbors.
And again, we better make sure that we don't screw up the one civilization that we have to deal with at the moment.
So yeah, I think that's another emerging view is that we're not nearly as plentiful as we once thought.
There's been some attention lately given to the fact that some asteroids are apparently dead comets, but of course the first two asteroids that were photographed turned out to be solid, hard rocks.
How common do you think it is for a comet to turn into an asteroid, or do you think in general they just sort of evaporate?
Well, I think they do both, actually.
I think some comets, once they
lost their volatile contents, certainly turned into asteroids, at least temporarily.

I think this comet, Shoemaker-Levy 9, that's about to collide with Jupiter next July is probably, my guess would be a degassed comet, a very fragile structure that was torn apart by the tidal forces of Jupiter in July of 92.
The line between comets and asteroids is no longer clearly drawn.
It's very fuzzy.
Comet Wilson-Harrington was seen in 1949.
It was rediscovered in 1979, VA, an asteroid.
So it was once active.
It is no longer.
So there's one example of a dead comet, if you will.
Perhaps it's only dormant.
These things could crust over.
And then at some later time, they might blow off a portion of the crust and become active again when the interior ices are exposed.
I think a fair fraction of the near-Earth asteroids were once comets.
Dynamically, it's much easier to explain the population if you have some comets coming in that way.
The estimates of the number of perihelion passes that a comet can make before something happens to it have varied all over the lot.
What do you think the situation is now?
Recently, fairly recently, the last couple of years, there's been a realization that comets can have periods where they're dormant.
They're active.
They're dormant.
They crust over, turn into or lose their bottles entirely.
So the estimates that we were seeing five or ten years ago whereby comets only last 500 or 1,000 returns to the sun, I think those estimates have to be revised up dramatically.
Comets like Encke have obviously been in its current orbit for millennia because
The Tauric meteor showers have been observed for millennia, although the comet itself wasn't observed until the late 1700s.

Barring differences due to the fact that some comets have longer periods than others and so see the sun more frequently or less frequently, do you think the structure of the nucleus of all comets is basically similar?
Certainly they're chemically similar.

For the spectroscopic work that's been done on periodic comets and long period comets, there are many differences between them, but there's no, you can't put the long period comets in one box and the short period comets in another and say these are chemically distinct from one another.
They just aren't.
There's some short period comets that are peculiar and some long period comets that are also peculiar.
But within some broad range, they're pretty much chemically the same animals, which suggests that they were all formed at the same time and probably at the same place.
Non-gravitational effects on cometary orbits is one of your specialties.
And part of that includes rotation of comet nuclei.
Have you folks come up with anything?
I mean, there's a random thing.
I mean, any correlation with period or anything.
Well, you can observe some active comments and note the jet structures coming out from the nucleus.
And from the shape of those jet structures, you can infer a rotation, certainly.
But you can't do the traditional photometric light curve analysis that you can on asteroids to get a rotation period.
The only thing you can really say with regard to comets, there are very few comets that have a reasonable rotation period determined.
I think there's only a half dozen or so.
They all seem to be a little longer than...
Asteroids of a comfortable size, I'm not sure what that means.
Perhaps they've been defunded by these same outgassing forces, I don't know.
But again, there's only a half dozen or so comets for which a reasonable rotation period has been determined.
And even those have large errors.
So it's still, I think, too early to say much about that.

Going back into the 19th century when the standard way of observing comets was to look through the telescope and eye magnification and draw the nucleus, with hindsight now you can look at some of the great comets of the last century and you can see the jets coming out from the hot spots and you can see the comet rotating as the jet swings around like a water hose.
Didn't people put two and two together back then, do you think?
Well, Bessel actually did put two and two together, but he was the exception.
He, back in, well, back in 1835, he actually proposed that there was some outgassing activity that was preferentially toward the sun.
and he made the example that if this outgassing occurred preferentially toward the Sun and preferentially before perihelion as opposed to after perihelion, you would get a

uh decreased in the commons period and likewise if the outgassing took place after perihelion preferentially you would get an increase in the commons period he didn't attribute this to outgassing in the sense that this is ice that was vaporizing but he came very close to whipple's uh
1950 model, even so.
And his idea for the non-gravs was actually more accurate than Fred's mechanism was for the non-gravitational effects.
But, again, it's a connection, I think, with the meteor showers and comets.
The meteors were obviously due to particles hitting the Earth's atmosphere
And so the inference was that comets were a collection of particles, a flying sandbank.
And I think that was the notion that was so ingrained and so obvious to most astronomers that these jets that you refer to, they made up ad hoc suggestions as to how to explain those.
There's another one on a similar line.
Well, Newton's laws of motion have been known for a long time, and action equals reaction have been known for a long time, and rockets have been around for a millennium.
And yet, as you mentioned earlier, the explanation of the non-gravitational effects, in particular on Encke, the first example, as due to a resisting medium, a mysterious medium of some sort,
hung around for a long time.
When did thatwhen and who first thought that this could bethat the rocket effect, if you will, could be the explanation?
Well, Encke, of course, as you noted, postulated that there was some sort of an ether surrounding thein the inner solar system, and Encke, in its
the prograde orbit around the sun was being slowed by this resisting medium.
It's unfortunate that the non-gravitational effects on Encke were in the sense that they were, in the sense that the period of Encke is decreasing.
Now, if they were increasing, and they are for many comments, he never would have been able to propose that.
particular mechanism, but it was just bad luck, I guess.
And this ether had been around for centuries, of course.
It started with the Greeks, gravitation.
So it was something that he brought back to explain these non-gravitational effects.
And the notion lingered for several decades thereafter.
But again, the first one who pointed out
a contrary view that these might be reactive forces acting on the comet's nucleus with vessels.
But his views did not carry the day because Encke's hypothesis, he could predict quite accurately the returns of his comet using his erroneous theory.
His model of the interplanetary ether
And the drag effects on his comet did indeed explain the decreasing period of his comet and allowed him to make very accurate predictions of when the comet would next appear at perihelion.
And so the fact that he was successfully predicting the comet's increasing period added considerable weight to what turned out to be an erroneous hypothesis.
One last question and then I'll let you go.
The sun graces all apparently belong to the same family and have a common parent.
Must have been an enormous body.
And of course, we haven't seen them all.
How can you score?
I mean, we're getting, if you add them all up, and goodness knows how many there are.
Now we're starting to get a fairly large body.
Certainly no Jupiter.
But how could that be?
Well, comets' parent bodies can be as large as, well, some might say Pluto is a very large comet.
Chiron may be a very large comet.
There's no real upper limit on the size of these things.
The progenitor for the sun-grating comet is thought to be the comet of 1106, perhaps 240 BC as well.
No, I'm sorry, that's Halley.
There's another one back there, though,
I forgot in the year that the Greeks actually noted the split.
But I think the comet of 1106 is thought by Brian to be the progenitor of many of the sun creatures, not all of them.
But that mechanism whereby a large parent comet breaking up into many smaller comets may well explain the preponderance of short period comets that we see now.
There are too many, far too many of them.
There are too many short-period comets for current theories to deal with.

So that splitting of major comets in the past, either spontaneous splitting or splitting because of tidal stresses like Shoemaker-Levy 9, may indeed not provide the answer for why there are so many short-period comets.
